content.raw:
the example fails to run if you don't have optix installed:

~~~
$ ./camera_tracking 
[Err] [RenderEngineManager.cc:94] No render-engine registered with name: optix
Engine 'optix' is not supported
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
~~~

Segmentation fault (core dumped)

content.raw:
I haven't gone through the code yet, but just from reading the documentation I have some preliminary comments:

1. Is the distinction between "tracking" and "following" described somewhere? I can guess from the names, but I'm not sure I fully got it
1. I see all offsets are given as `Vector3`, which I take to mean the XYZ translation. Is there a way to choose which angle to track from? For example, tracking a car by looking at it from the front or from the back or from a side?
content.html:
I haven't gone through the code yet, but just from reading the documentation I have some preliminary comments:

  1. Is the distinction between "tracking" and "following" described somewhere? I can guess from the names, but I'm not sure I fully got it
  2. I see all offsets are given as Vector3, which I take to mean the XYZ translation. Is there a way to choose which angle to track from? For example, tracking a car by looking at it from the front or from the back or from a side?

content.raw: I concur, it wasn't obvious to me the difference between tracking and following. I had to read the example code and look at the function calls to figure out what each function meant. My understanding is that "track" means the camera points at something, and "follow" means the camera translates relative to something.
content.html: I concur, it wasn't obvious to me the difference between tracking and following. I had to read the example code and look at the function calls to figure out what each function meant. My understanding is that "track" means the camera points at something, and "follow" means the camera translates relative to something.

content.raw: After trying the demo I think you're right
content.html: After trying the demo I think you're right

content.raw: Ah ok it only works on `1 - Fixed camera` mode (which is a bit counter-intuitive to me, I can only move the camera when it is fixed :thinking: )
content.html: Ah ok it only works on 1 - Fixed camera mode (which is a bit counter-intuitive to me, I can only move the camera when it is fixed )

content.raw: I guess fixed means it's not tethered, sorry for thinking in public
content.html: I guess fixed means it's not tethered, sorry for thinking in public

content.raw: The mouse interactions need to be updated. Typical orbit view controller doesn't work well when camera tracking and following is on.  I'll work on that separately.
content.html: The mouse interactions need to be updated. Typical orbit view controller doesn't work well when camera tracking and following is on. I'll work on that separately.

content.raw: Could we add `Set*Offset` functions so the offsets can be changed on the fly without the need to re-set the target?
content.html: Could we add Set*Offset functions so the offsets can be changed on the fly without the need to re-set the target?

content.raw: I added them on 75c0a69, feel free to merge if you agree. Also tied them to keys on the demo.
content.html: I added them on 75c0a69, feel free to merge if you agree. Also tied them to keys on the demo.

content.raw: thanks, merged! 7e72eec
content.html: thanks, merged! 7e72eec

content.raw: Do you think there is a use case for a `worldFrame` option on `SetTrackTarget`? For example, track a spinning top but keeping it on the right side of the image instead of the center.
content.html: Do you think there is a use case for a worldFrame option on SetTrackTarget? For example, track a spinning top but keeping it on the right side of the image instead of the center.

content.raw: makes sense. I added an optional arg to allow camera tracking offset in world frame and updated tests. 31c6cf7 and 0e25d6d
content.html: makes sense. I added an optional arg to allow camera tracking offset in world frame and updated tests. 31c6cf7 and 0e25d6d
